results.title: The Origin of life
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, Adrian Malone and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Adapted from Cosmos the television series by Carl Sagan, this film examines the role of the nucleus in cell activity; describes the process by which an identical genetic message can be made for each cell in a living organism; shows the commonality of all living things on earth and recreates an experimental attempt to duplicate the formation of the first complex organic molecules on earth. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, Adrian Malone and Films Incorporated

results.title: The Organisers
results.creator_credit: Roger Owen, Anthony Cash and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”.
How far do organisers think in educational terms? Have they a philosophy of adult education? Do they know the environment they serve? Are they concerned with the actual quality of the teaching that goes on in their area or college.

results.title: The Organ. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Muir Mathieson and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Simon Preston, speaking from the console of the great Harrison organ in Westminster Abbey, tells of the history and construction of the instrument. He explains the simple theory of sound generation, the problems of providing constant air pressure, and the complexities of playing. Works by Mozart, Purcell and others are played.

results.title: The Orchestra
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Muir Mathieson, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
The formation, selection and training of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain. Spotlights each section of the orchestra as they rehearse subtleties of intonation and phrasing until something like perfection is achieved. Then they perform Dvorak’s Carnival Overture.

results.title: The Orchard, timber yard, Oakbank farm
results.creator_credit: James Mann, Chris O'Rourke and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People Who Help Us”.
This program looks at three different work environments, an apple orchard a timber yard and a children’s animal farm. We see the people who work there, find out what each job entails and the process used to accomplish the various tasks involved.

results.title: The Orange grower
results.brief_description: The story of an orange-grower and his family in the citrus fruit growing area of USA and how they raise and harvest their crop. Budding, pruning, planting, fertilising, irrigating, controlling weeds and pests, and combating extremes of temperature, are shown in detail.
results.description: The story of an orange-grower and his family in the citrus fruit growing area of USA and how they raise and harvest their crop. Budding, pruning, planting, fertilising, irrigating, controlling weeds and pests, and combating extremes of temperature, are shown in detail.

results.title: The Opposite sex. Parts 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Robin Hughes and Robin Hughes and Associates
results.brief_description: Part 3. Sex and emotion uncovers the complex interplay between hormones, experience and emotional behaviour and poses the question “In a world past the bomb, are we still unconsciously toughening our boys for hand to hand combat? and in a world past the pill, are our girls still being reared for a lifetime of childbearing?” “Part 4. Sex and society” Out in the world, as opposed to alone, the contrast between the sexes is striking. This episode traces the development of boys and girls from birth to discover how the gulf between masculine and feminine behaviour is created. The programs are interspersed with comments from ordinary people as well as experts to show the wide range of opinion from stereotype to enlightened.

results.title: The Opposite sex. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Robin Hughes and Robin Hughes and Associates
results.brief_description: Dr. Norman Swan narrates this four part series on the differences between men and women. “Part 1. Sex and gender” investigates sexuality and what makes people sexually attractive to each other, concluding that more than the sum of genes, hormones and upbringing is involved. “Part 2. Sex and ability” poses the question “is there such a thing as a male or female brain?” and examines the latest research on the brain. Each program is interspersed with the personal views of ordinary people as well as experts, to demonstrate the range from stereotype to enlightened.
